Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Software Safety: Methodology, Practice and Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a successful CISE Research Experiences for
Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Texas at Dallas.
This site focuses on Software Engineering research related to
Software Safety. Students will evaluate the strengths and
weakness of existing methodologies and current practices for
safety assurance, as well as investigating issues such as how
the introduction of software safety requirements may affect
the software lifecycle and how software processes, methods
and tool support should be adjusted. In addition to research,
students will take field trips to industrial partners and attend
mentoring workshops on technical writing and oral presentation.

This REU site will allow students, especially those from
underrepresented groups or universities with limited research
opportunities, to experience cutting-edge research in software
safety --- critical to the prevention of catastrophic accidents
and safe operation of software-dependent systems. It will also
encourage these students to continue into graduate programs and
careers in science and technology research. Students will gain
proficiency in a broadly applicable skill set including oral
and written communication, research methods, critical thinking,
and problem solving.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Software today plays a significant role in controlling the behavior of many systems, including safety-critical applications. A hazard realized directly or indeirectly through software's operation can have catastrophic consequences, including property damage, financial loss, and serious injury or death. Preventing such disasters from occurring is thus of paramount importance.

An REU site at the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) has been established where undergraduates, under close UTD faculty supervision, conduct research focusing on how to produce safe software more efficiently and effectively. Each student attends lectures at the beginning of the program to improve competency in software safety before engaging in a specially designated project matching his or her interests and academic strengths. Workshops on technical writing and oral presentation are held to imporve students' proficiency in preparing and delivering technical reports. Seminars on ethics and professional responsibilities are also given to ensure REU students behave properly and respectfully. Field trips to our industry parteners allow students to speak directly to practitioners and better understand how software safety is applied to real-life projects. Interactions between REU students, faculty mentors and graduate students are emphasized. In addition to individual research, teamwork is also encouraged. Follow-ups are conducted to prepare students for presentations at workshops and conferences as well as for graduate school applications. A nation-wide call for participation is used to rectuir ten students each summer. Up to five are from UTD or neighboring EPSCoR states. Priority is given to underrepresented minorties, women, persons with disabilities, and students from institutions with limited research resources. Each recruit has a background in Computer Science or Software Engineering.

The subject of this REU project is software safety with a focus on evaluating the strengths and weaknesses if existing methodologies and current practices for safety assurance; investigating issues such as how the introduction of software safety requirements may affect the software lifecycle; and studying how software processes, methods and tool support should be accordingly adjusted. Further exploration emphasizes the potentail impact of the emerging IoT (Internet of Things), especially its scalability and heterogeneity, on software safety.

A study on cost-effectiveness is conducted to answer questions such as "Will safe software cost more to produce?" Our findings provide a comprehensive picture of how software safety can be achieved effectively and efficiently without imposing extra cost. An extensive analysis of recent software-related accidents is performed so that the lessons learned can help prevent the same mistakes from recurring. A significant distinction of this project is its mutually beneficial synergy with another project, "Foundational Requirements for Competency in Software Safety," sponsored by Hewlett Packard via an NSF funded I/UCRC. Another distinction of this project is a close collaboration with industry via an Advisory Board of several distinguished members.

As software safety is key in safe operation of many systems and in reduction of catastrophic accidents, this project provides cutting-edge research opportunities to the selected students, espeically those from underrepresented groups or universities with limited resources. After gaining skills in critical thinking, oral and written communication, problem solving, and research methods, our REU students are encouraged and well prepared for graduate education and research careers in science and technology.
